definition: to announce to the world (idiom)/to make public/to let everyone know

public/collectively owned/common/international (e.g. high seas, metric system, calendar)/make public/fair/just/Duke, highest of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/honorable (gentlemen)/father-in-law/male (animal)
surname Zhu
all/various
surname Yu
to go/to take/sentence-final interrogative particle/variant of 於|于[yu2]
in/at/to/from/by/than/out of
surname Shi
life/age/generation/era/world/lifetime/epoch/descendant/noble

sentences.english: I wish to make this matter known to the general public.
sentences.chinese: 我想要把这件事公诸于世。

sentences.english: This post is about the reason why I haven't been updating my blog.
sentences.chinese: 这一篇是要将为何好久没有更新的原因公诸于世。

sentences.english: Before the matter was publicly announced, it had long been in the air.
sentences.chinese: 这件事在公诸于世之前早就传得满城风雨。

sentences.english: The proposed sale could be announced by Monday morning, the report said.
sentences.chinese: 有报道称，这项交易将于周一早上被公诸于世。

sentences.english: We have peaceably assembled here, as is our right, to let these facts be known.
sentences.chinese: 我们有权在这里和平集会，并将这些事实公诸于世。

sentences.english: Bofore the matter was publicly announced, it had long been in the air.
sentences.chinese: 这件事在公诸于世之前早就传得满城风雨了。

sentences.english: Many new discoveries have been brought to light.
sentences.chinese: 许多新发现已公诸于世。

sentences.english: It’s surely only a matter of time before Microsoft unleashes its iPad killer on the world.
sentences.chinese: 微软将其iPad杀手公诸于世将仅仅是个时间问题。

sentences.english: The part written in cipher – turned out after examination to be entirely unpublishable.
sentences.chinese: 用密码记录的内容，经过检视完全不能公诸于世。

definition: to announce to the world (idiom)/to make public/to let everyone know
to make known to the masses (idiom); to publicize widely/to let the world know
to expose/to unmask/to ferret out/to disclose/disclosure
to expose/to bring to light/to disclose/revelation
to be thoroughly discredited/to fall into disrepute
the truth about sth/the actual facts
the whole truth is revealed (idiom); everything becomes clear
scandal
scandal
to lose one's standing/to have one's reputation swept away/a complete defeat and fall from grace
to uncover
irrefutable evidence
to expose/to uncover
(of a plot etc) to fall through and stand exposed
known by everyone (idiom); well known/a household name
evil or wicked conduct
